sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations with noisy data
message_1:
Consider the following system of equations:

$x + 2y + z = 9$

$2x + 5y + 4z = 30$

$3x + 6y + 5z = 44$

However, due to measurement error, the second equation is actually $2x + 5.3y + 3.8z = 29.4$. Use linear algebra methods to solve for $x$, $y$, and $z$.
message_2:
To solve this system of equations using linear algebra, we can represent it as a matrix equation AX = B, where A is the matrix of coefficients, X is the column vector of variables, and B is the column vector of constants.

Given the corrected system of equations:

$x + 2y + z = 9$

$2x + 5.3y + 3.8z = 29.4$

$3x + 6y + 5z = 44$

We can represent this as:

A = $\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 5.3 & 3.8 \\ 3 & 6 & 5 \end{bmatrix}$, X = $\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix}$, and B = $\begin{bmatrix} 9 \\ 29.4 \\ 44 \end{bmatrix}$

To find X, we can use the inverse of matrix A, such that X = A⁻¹B.

First, we need to find the inverse of A (A⁻¹). We can do this using the formula A⁻¹ = (1/|A|)adj(A), where |A| is the determinant of A and adj(A) is the adjugate of A.

To find the determinant of A:

|A| = $\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 5.3 & 3.8 \\ 3 & 6 & 5 \end{vmatrix}$ = $1\begin{vmatrix} 5.3 & 3.8 \\ 6 & 5 \end{vmatrix} - 2\begin{vmatrix} 2 & 3.8 \\ 3 & 5 \end{vmatrix} + 1\begin{vmatrix} 2 & 5.3 \\ 3 & 6 \end{vmatrix}$

|A| = $1(5.3\times5 - 3.8\times6) - 2(2\times5 - 3.8\times3) + 1(2\times6 - 5.3\times3)$

|A| = $1(26.5 - 22.8) - 2(10 - 11.4) + 1(12 - 15.9)$

|A| = $1(3.7) - 2(-1.4) + 1(-3.9)$

|A| = $3.7 + 2.8 - 3.9$

|A| = $2.6$

Now, we need to find the adjugate of A:

adj(A) = $\begin{bmatrix} \begin{vmatrix} 5.3 & 3.8 \\ 6 & 5 \end{vmatrix} & -\begin{vmatrix} 2 & 3.8 \\ 3 & 5 \end{vmatrix} & \begin{vmatrix} 2 & 5.3 \\ 3 & 6 \end{vmatrix} \\ -\begin{vmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 3 & 5 \end{vmatrix} & \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 3 & 5 \end{vmatrix} & -\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 6 \end{vmatrix} \\ \begin{vmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 5.3 & 3.8 \end{vmatrix} & -\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 3.8 \end{vmatrix} & \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 5.3 \end{vmatrix} \end{bmatrix}$

adj(A) = $\begin{bmatrix} (5.3\times5 - 3.8\times6) & -(2\times5 - 3.8\times3) & (2\times6 - 5.3\times3) \\ -(2\times5 - 1\times3) & (1\times5 - 1\times3) & -(1\times6 - 2\times3) \\ (2\times3.8 - 1\times5.3) & -(1\times3.8 - 1\times2) & (1\times5.3 - 2\times2) \end{bmatrix}$

adj(A) = $\begin{bmatrix} 3.7 & 1.4 & -3.9 \\ -7 & 2 & -2 \\ 0.7 & 0.6 & 1.3 \end{bmatrix}$

Now, we can find the inverse of A:

A⁻¹ = (1/|A|)adj(A) = $\frac{1}{2.6}\begin{bmatrix} 3.7 & 1.4 & -3.9 \\ -7 & 2 & -2 \\ 0.7 & 0.6 & 1.3 \end{bmatrix}$

A⁻¹ = $\begin{bmatrix} 1.423 & 0.538 & -1.5 \\ -2.692 & 0.769 & -0.769 \\ 0.269 & 0.231 & 0.5 \end{bmatrix}$

Now, we can find X by multiplying A⁻¹ and B:

X = A⁻¹B = $\begin{bmatrix} 1.423 & 0.538 & -1.5 \\ -2.692 & 0.769 & -0.769 \\ 0.269 & 0.231 & 0.5 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 9 \\ 29.4 \\ 44 \end{bmatrix}$

X = $\begin{bmatrix} (1.423\times9 + 0.538\times29.4 - 1.5\times44) \\ (-2.692\times9 + 0.769\times29.4 - 0.769\times44) \\ (0.269\times9 + 0.231\times29.4 + 0.5\times44) \end{bmatrix}$

X = $\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix}$ = $\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix}$

So, the solution to the system of equations is x = 1, y = 2, and z = 3.
